Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56624795
Most of those are probably marked 223 for import restriction reasons in other countries where 223 Remington is considered a civilian caliber and is legal whereas 5.56mm isn't, even though they can shoot both.

For instance the Ruger and S&W rifles listed there can fire 5.56mm just fine. Typically they have a "223 Wylde" chamber which is an intermediate between 223 and 5.56, allowing it to be a little tighter and theoretically more accurate than 5.56 but able to fire both without issues.
Even a true 223 Remington chamber can usually handle 5.56, the dimensional and pressure difference is very minor. It's not like 357 Magnum vs 38 Special.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56578822
Why do you want one?
For example i chose a Tavor7 because having the balance of a bullpup with the chambering and weight of a battle rifle makes a rifle easy to carry, hike and shoot with. I have a rifle that with good stance and control i can send 147gr slugs with rapidity into the brush close up and if need be I also can shoot over a valley 600-800m away and have decent success with heavy winds. Besides just being a cool configuration bullpups do have advantages and disadvantages. Nothing is ever for free. Laying prone with extended mags, reloading from prone, reloading in general is a tad slower but that isn't so much a disadvantage as everyone highlights. I guess if you plan on 1v6 ing a bunch of people you may want to reconsider another platform.

Overall i would say that a lot of bullpups suffer from adequate forends. I've seen some sweet AUGs with nice forends that allow good control and attachment space. Another thing a good forend allows is space to brace. The Tavors generally have a cutlass grip and shorter rails which is nice for stabilizing in some ways but also now you have a single pivot point and when you're trying to keep steady for a 400m+ shot, you get a lot of vertical play. I wish the Tavor7 had just 2-3 more inches and i would be super happy with that as i have long arms and it feels more comfortable with longer shots. That's my coffee induced reply so take it as it is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56609202
>And didn't it have some really weird ejection system, where like it stored 5 spent cartridges at a time then ejected them all at once?
It has a chute running from the ejection port to the front of the gun that takes a few rounds to fill up to the point that cases start getting pushed out. Because the ejection port isn't accessible with the gun assembled, you have to do all your chamber checks and malfunction diagnosis through the little toilet bowl lid at the back of the optic rail.

>but also seems like a lot of unnecessary mass
It's mostly hollow plastic; internally it's just Steyr's homework with some of the answers changed.

>Still would be fun to try one if it's ever available to rent on the range or a friend gets one.
I've shot a range rental; it was very mid. The rubber skirt inside the magwell makes reloads very slow, the charging handle is plastic and won't tolerate being HK slapped, and it generally feels not-quite-right but not-exactly-wrong, like is was designed by a Martian who knew what hands were for but had no personal experience using them. It's fully ambi, but otherwise feels like the bullpup that people who hate bullpups think all bullpups are like.

>Which bullpups suppress decently out of the box? I am partial to the AUG fwiw
Other anons have posted about the limits and options for the aug. The MDRX is probably be the best suppressor straight out of the box, with a 6 position adjustable gas and 30cal option. You'll be able to achieve as good suppression as possible using any can you want. Higher back pressure cans still offer the best pure performance.

But improving low omega flowthrough cans like the 556k definitely have shaken things up. They don't perform quite as well but they're still solid and they make it possible to suppress guns not actually built for it. Aug though is a special case due to the gas port but again see solutions above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56617420
Yeah, 556 simply does not suppress well, on anything at all, period. That said, I'd suggest using earpro alongside cans for any rifle unless you're getting into truly quiet subsonic stuff. Suppressors help a ton, going from 160-175dB down to 120-140dB is a huge help particularly since it doubles up perfectly and works even in an emergency. But that's still LOUD. Don't believe industry horseshit about how <140dB is "hearing safe", that's merely the level at which you don't suffer significant instantaneous permanent hearing loss. But you shouldn't be dealing with that kind of noise for lots of shooting, and being near any sort of hard objects (particularly indoors) that can reflect sound can increase exposrue as well. Pic related, NIOSH guidelines for actual real work.

Advantage of suppression is that plain earpro maxes out at ~40dB reduction, and that's if you do everything perfectly. Suppressor means you can get away with cheaper, easier 20-30dB earpro and still be fine, and you've got safety margin in case of bad fit or marginal conditions (like indoor range or next to cliffs or something) etc. It should be a basic cheap OTC safety option like in a lot of the EU even. FUCK the NFA.

Still worth the trouble imo. At least the raw rate of things getting worse has slowed down even if they haven't gotten better. I guess. Fuck.

Note that CA now has a funky "ranking" system for LEOs when it comes to off-roster pistols. Some can buy them but not sell them to non-LEOs/FFLs, some can do both, some are completely prohibited, etc. For example actual PD officers can get them without restrictions, but California Horse Racing Board and Law Enforcement Branch of the Office of Emergency Services investigators can only use off-roster if issued as their service weapon (and forget about buying/selling on their own).

https://oag.ca.gov/firearms/exemptpo
https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displaySection.xhtml?sectionNum=32000&lawCode=PEN

>>56623392
In 1955 the US military assessed the Warsaw Pact could field 155 divisions with minimal preparation and close to 250 within 90 days of the outbreak of hostilities NATO? A mere 25 on D-Day, and 50 in total within 90 days.
The ratio shifted back and forth (with the rearmament of Germany helping NATO significantly) over the next few decades but the Soviets always had the advantage of numbers.
NATO always had a qualitative superiority over the Warsaw Pact, but it was the 1980s before the gap started to become decisive in and of itself.
The use of tactical nuclear weapons was regarded as a wildcard by both sides, with each preferring not to use them as long as possible.
The Soviets were *always* a major threat to the West even if you discount the overestimation of their equipment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56623554
One of the flawed assumptions NATO was operating under throughout the Cold War was that Soviet conscripts would be comparable to Western conscripts and short-service volunteers.
Take the US experience in Vietnam. Our problem with using conscription was that many of the men drafted simply did not want to be there. But our conscripts were trained infantry and tankers, even helicopter pilots, and they acquitted themselves well enough in combat.
What killed conscription in the US was a combination of political pressure, widespread drug use, and growing discipline problems across the entire army (look up the statistics about how many US troops, even in places as far away from Vietnam and the US as Germany, were using heroin in mid-70s, the sudden phenomenon of "fragging", and of course, the persistent stories about how on certain bases the officers simply didn't enter the barracks without an armed escort).

Looking for re-loading anons who know what happened here:

I bid at an auction house that started their own bidding platform which no one uses so I get stuff for insanely cheap. He's been selling off a large estate and I've gotten plenty of surplus/commercial/some reloads for basically nothing. I've had no issues with the commercial and surplus stuff and most of the reloads are well marked and fine. I ended up getting a bag of 13 8mm Mauser with Remington brass for $1.75.

Was shooting my Romanian Vz24 yesterday which has never had an issues, shot a box of PPU of it without problem. First reload is noticeably lighter recoil than the PPU but I still had an impact on my 50 yard target from it. Round two is a little heavier on recoil but still has a good hit at 50 yards. Third round I pull the trigger and I feel a burning sensation on my forehead. Gas escaped through somewhere and spat back. Case had a large dark spot on the rim. I fired the next two rounds basically from the hip at a berm close by and felt gas on one and not the other. These were all lighter recoil than the PPU. Doesn't seem like it would be an overloaded round with lighter recoil. Chance the bullet wasn't seated properly and caused gases to escape?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It´s usually not that instant, there´s usually some delay on just calling in a regular fire mission. There´s dude with huge radars who figure out where artillery comes from, and they then have to figure out which unit to call up to do the counter-strike, and those guys need some time to set up too.

If you expect your mortars to get countered you set them up near a basement or get them outta there as quickly as possible, the more mobile units just shoot and scoot.

Because it´s somewhat predictable and survivable, counter battery fire doesn´t flat out stop the enemy from doing their thing, it usually just limits them to doing shorter burts and having to relocate. Which is still worth it.

>>56619930
Had a time delay and used to take a lot of training and prep.

Autonomous mortars from modular 60mms you can pop onto IFVs or treaded drones to autonomous 120mm mortars and 155mm howitzers are a thing now.

Add in drones for spotting and drones up with full EM sensors for pinpointing any fire coming in, plus a networked deep learning trained system for prioritizing fire missions and picking suitable munitions for each target and it is going to become incredibly rapid.

Final step will be semi autonomous supply vehicles that can get to batteries and reload systems with little to no human intervention, but that's a bit further.

But just having spotter drones everywhere and having every rifle's ballistics computer/range finder able to send in anything from the squad vehicles' small mortar to the autonomous batteries big guns almost instantly is going to change warfare dramatically over the next decade.

Whoever loses control of the low altitude airspace and runs out of interception capabilities first is fucked.

>>56620596
In the modern era, drones help. In the ye olden days of the First World War (and even into the Korean War in limited circumstances), they relied on detecting the flash from artillery firing or recording the sound of distance cannon fire for analysis.
The latter was surprisingly sophisticated for 1910s but the telephone and phonograph had made audio recording a relatively mature technology. The equipment of the day could make records accurate to a hundredth of a second, and by using two sound detectors and trigonometry they could (under ideal conditions) get a fix on an enemy artillery battery that was accurate to fifty meters or less.

I had to dig up an email chain from 1996 about a German magazine article from 1987 about this conversion to find out about it.

Apparently, Interarms bought a bunch of shitty M94's from the Swedish army back in 1955 and had some of them sent to Madsen in Denmark for rebarreling. Some got converted into 7x57mm and sent to Central America, and some got converted to the newly designed 308Win and sent god knows where.

One of them ended up at an auction near me. Got it for $480. The bore's pristine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56602781
Here are some good drawings of original early guns: https://feuerwaffen.ch/drawings.htm
It looks like most matchlocks had the pan brazed/soldered/? directly to the barrel, and the lock + serpentine was located to allow for operation of the trigger/lever and contact of the match with the pan. The 1500 wall gun pictures show this really clearly. I’ve seen some locks where it seems the pan is incorporated into the lock plate as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56608905
Standard loading for that would be .440 dia round balls, .010" thick patches, and 3F powder, aka FFFG, or Pyrodex "P". Charge between 20 and 30 grains.

For "speedloading" there are plastic "charge tubes" which you can pre-assemble loads in. Or you could make old-school paper cartridges like people did for muskets back in the day. In that case the paper wrapping would replace the patch: you'd tear the top off the paper cart, pour the powder down the barrel, then use the paper part as the patch/wad as you rammed it down.

>>56617637

Apply for a think tank; low-tier you're making $40k a year but if you move up into higher analyst posts you can make serious bank ($100k+). And all you have to do is think about stuff, cite sources, and give an opinion. The more niche and complicated the subject, the more money you can make.

Topics can range from:
Explosives
Ships
Aircraft
Weather conditions affecting combined arms warfare.
Geopolitics
Historical/Cultural trends
Natural explanations for military doctrines
SIGINT and Radar systems
Intelligence Operations
Environmental/Geological trends
Mining and Resources
Agriculture

Expect to read a lot. Expect to write a lot. Expect to have evidence to back up your analysis.

Best thing is you're often working along or with a small group of like-minded nerds.

Loans and financing cause inflation.
It allows most to buy something they cannot afford, increasing demand, which increases the cost. Before loans were common and debtors prison existed a home in America cost 3-5 years of typical income or less (or nearly free if you went to the frontier and dealt with native raids, bandits, and poor infrastructure as a homestead.) But it required self control and saving.
Once mortgages were normal it quickly increased from 10 years to 15, to 20 and now 30 year mortgages. Mortgages increase demand on limited supply, increasing costs. Same with anything financed.
Cars have become even more expensive since leasing added a few more years of financing beyond the 5 years to purchase in just the last 10 years. And now they dont even advertise payments to buy, only to lease a new car in commercials. They lease them 3 years then sell them for what they cost new a decade ago for another 5 years of financing.

The founders tried to prevent jewish settlers and european banking from coming over.
But the problem is in a global economy if you prevent your own citizens from using credit foreign credit buys up everything, only at lower prices. Like current chinese backed loans buy up american land, but even worse.

Essentially as long as money lending exists somewhere in the world it can be used to buy out the places it is not allowed, if not directly then through finance and commodity manipulation, so you cannot stop it.

>>56623571
Soviet money didnt really mean much. The state fixed prices and salaries in a random way so any deficit could be papered with loans you had to pay back except you didn't have to. For instance soviet farms were operating in the 60s with fixed crop prices from 1923, and they made nearly zero income from selling crops. All their income came from loans that they never paid back.
Meanwhile all workers got paid far more than there were products to buy. Most of this money just piled up in people's homes and didn't cause (much) inflation except at the black market and during the 80s when stores were allowed to raise prices in a serious way.
Bottom line money meant little. People could live fine with no income or very bad with a high income. Nothing was done consistently, having the state have a policy to forgive your debts if you had kids didn't mean it would happen in reality, it all depended on luck and the mood of specific bureocrats.

>>56620248
They adjusted the artilery mechanics somewhat, you can still look manually for enemy trenchlines during the initial orders phase and queue artillery based on that (which is somewhat realistic I suppose). You can also still guess, based on the combat area, where the units are most likely to spawn and preemptively strike them.

They changed the on-map artillery mechanics though, so any given unit can do direct fire if it's capable of spotting a target, but in order to do indirect fire you need a spotter in the chain of command somewhere with visual on the target. He also needs to stay in place for a few minutes. You also, afaik, cannot micromanage the target of individual guns, an entire battery will launch on your chosen point and that's it.

I believe these changes were implemented for Mius Front for exactly the reason you're describing.

With Squad I think it has the same problem Foxhole has, a reliance on logi with a lack of players/systems to actually do that logi properly.

In Foxhole it's partisans waiting until a hex is queued (generally by clans) then ambushing logi in the next hex, choking the queued hex until the people inside it leave so logi can run the blockade and get in (unlikely, doubly so if it's a clan doing tank ops since they are super salty about leaving their tanks for any reason), then the entire hex collapses all at once and people complain in world chat. The problem isn't the gunplay or the teams, it's the way the servers are set up.

In Squad it's literally one combat engineer placing mines, or one squad setting up a TOW in a mountainous region. Although the players on a lot of servers will complain /violently/ when you do this, it's actually the most effective way to win on a lot of maps. Just like Foxhole, the game is set up to reward this behavior.

Yes, absolutely. It's an inherent problem with a public game trying to be tactical. People aren't good enough at tactics and gamesense to pull off the kind of shit you can do individually as a group. You'd need other real autistic tryhards who want to cooperate seriously as a unit and under strict militaristic leadership, but those kind of people have little reason to play Squad over something like Apex, so you don't find it anywhere.

Playing as a squad is actually the worse option once the HAB is placed and the initial surprise is lost, since moving alone you can get inside the enemy's OODA loop: take wild flanks, surprise enemies with ease, find all their FOBs, escape the enemy focus since you're just one guy and so forth.
Sticking to your squad is just a waste of effort for a genuinely great FPS player, since outside of singular surprise attacks, you'll always be stuck slamming yourself directly into the enemy in an effort to force numbers into the cap and so you can't actually contribute much to anything.
The fight is too fair whenever you're frontally taking someone on, and you're just another body in the zone basically and that's something any blueberry can fulfill.

Moving alone I've wiped whole squads on my own, gotten +80 (very much objective related) kills in a single match as infantry multiple times, crumbled entire attacks just by finding an enemy FOB or logi trying to build it, etc. more times than I can recall. All because moving on my own instead of as a part of the squad allows me to sneak myself inside the enemy squads' decision making loops.

>>56620593
Wargame 10v10 MP is a uniquely great tool for practice and study of combined arms warfare at the company and battalion scale, and understanding how to be an effective commander during an engagement. Games often run larger but the simulation accuracy degrades for a variety of reasons. Where it shines is creating real-time situations against other commanders for you to respond to and challenge your knowledge. Many incidents caught on camera in Ukraine attest to Wargame's overall accuracy, though it's important to consider what it omits like minefields/combat engineering. It's especially effective if played in a private group with other enthusiasts or professionals (war college, ROTC) using realistic doctrine and orders of battle.

To get good >>56620614 has the right idea. I advise learning the basic mechanics in the solo campaigns. Don't stick with it too long, they're fun but the ai plays nothing like a human and is exploitable, it competes via cheating so you'll learn bad habits. Next, spend an hour comparing units you liked/hated/feared from the campaign and build a basic deck with some of them. Don't worry about filling every slot or following a meta, you won't have the skill to succeed with it yet. I advise starting with specialty decks in 5000pt 10v10 "tactical" servers. Give yourself a mission, like "I will prevent a bridge crossing", "I will sneak special forces into this backline capture zone to identify and ambush opportunity targets" or "I will provide artillery support in this sector", and just focus on controlling and succeeding with the small cluster of units needed to accomplish it. Expect to lose badly or feel like you didn't help the team win, everyone starts that way. After a few games you'll get the flow of battle better and can more effectively command the various units you'll need to succeed. Then you start fine-tuning your deck, studying the mechanics, trying new nations and different gametypes.

>>56624809
Indeed, and the attention to fun and accessibility paid dividends with the large unit variety and multiplayer options. The hard-sim classics struggle to replicate the real-time command experience with an exploitable ai or limited multiplayer support - two divisions in a meeting engagement have over a dozen specialized battalion COs on each side who need to coordinate and cooperate. Wargame doesn't force this, but it's one of the few games that gives you the option to try.
It means you'll see and learn authentic circumstances that lead to situations like the infantry "CO" from a different or foreign division screaming and cursing at someone else for not providing air/arty support, or worse allchat. Says a lot about the situation in the staff tent when it happens IRL, like the Russians at the battle for Irpin/Bucha/Hostomel. Nothing quite like listening to their clusterfuck play out via a HAM repeater.

posts.name: A2Grip
posts.com:
/arg/ Tasks of the month for Jan-2023
Maintenance-
Optics are useful on your rifle but they only work when you respect them, part of this is cleaning them.
>Do you have a lens blower?
>Do you have a lens brush?
>Do you have lens paper?
>Do you have lens cleaner?
How do you intend to carry this into the field with you?
You should at this point know how your optics degrade in relation to how dirty they get. Next time your optic is filthy take the opportunity to observe assorted distances at various times throughout the day to see how much clarity you lose.

Skill Sustainment-
Target: 9x9” Plate or similar paper
Rounds: 2-4 rounds
Equipment: SPR
After confirming zero at 100yd walk back to 200yd.
Action: Upon buzzer start standing @ low ready (real low ready, not wgws low ready), Drop to a knee and deliver two solid hits on the 9x9 plate and call your time. Add 1 second for each dropped shot
Total times (time+dropped penalty):
>Cold 9 sec = Par
>Warmed up 8 sec = par
>6 and below = cooking it
Record your times and experiment with the mag level on your SPR.

Improvement-
If you are using a harris or similar force to overcome style bipod you can improve deployment speed with a quick mod at home.
Get a 12” long piece of paracord and tie an overhand knot over itself 3 times in the center, some people like to leave a tail on longer guns. Grab one end of the line and tie it to a harris bipod leg above the release button with a suitable knot, repeat on the other leg. To deploy; pinch the knot or grasp the line that dangles between the legs when folded and yank down with a jerk motion. It will deploy both legs at once and doesn’t require you to reach across the bipod or juggle the gun when prone. More documentation: https://ridgelineshooting.com/bipod-paracord-hack/ and https://youtu.be/21Azmj0rJQ0

Post task of month times/feedback in thread

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Stuff like pic rel would be an example of a very basic engraving job done by hand. Even this sort of work is somewhere between 20 and 30 hours per action, making it a 1k+ job at current prices. The issue is that the vast majority of gun owners do not buy one or two high quality pieces and hand them down to their children but rather buy multiple cheap throw away items. It is a result of budget constraints and the desire for instant consumption. We could have a lengthy discussion about the economic principle and utilitarian approaches to objects, but in the end it is about financial constraints.
People are not willing to spend 150% of the price of their firearm for a basic engraving job when they are buying at the low end of the price spectrum. Cheaper types of engraving will always look cheap, which defeats the entire purpose of the job: making the gun into a piece of art.
That is why I would argue that offering engraving for anything but middle to high tier weapons is pointless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56601289
I think an important detail to mention is that the economics have changed over the years.
Over a hundred years ago when a gun was still made mostly by hand labor was a lot cheaper than it is now. The cost of engraving a gun was a very small fraction of the total cost to make it so it really wasn't any big deal to do so. Today things are totally different, factory autmation is used to make guns, skilled labor like engraving is terribly expensive by comparison. So, we either get cheap-and-fast shortcuts, like stamping, laser, etc, or you pay out the nose for a high end gun that still has a lot of handwork. Same thing applies to checkering too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56601289
>which defeats the entire purpose of the job: making the gun into a piece of art.
That was always my take on it. And I think for the really fancy stuff posted here it's certainly true. But I was reading picrel the other day and it raised a very interesting, and practical, point:
Back in the day the cost of engraving was low unless you were talking about some super high exhibition piece. And the engraving did serve a useful function: it obscures the inevitable scratches and dings that a gun develops as its used. If you had a completely plain receiver, lockplate, etc, it would show every defect just like stains on a white sheet. But if there's some pattern or design on there it distracts you from seeing the scratch.

>>56615400
>>56615465

It's not just lunar hay fever (that's it's actual name) that's a problem, moon dust fucks the shit out of pretty much anything unshielded on the lunar surface. Devices with exposed moving parts such as rovers are effected the worst by the dust's abrasion, but apparently it can also cause significant damage to spacesuit visors and fabric coatings.

Luckily some of the most godawful properties of lunar dust are caused by it's negative charge, meaning it's pretty easy to get rid of for the most part with static electricity. NASA has so far found pretty great success with both electrostatic layers and low-energy electric "scrubbers" for removing dust. While said protection will likely add a fair amount of weight to any future colony, it's probaly cheaper than the alternative fo replacing everything five times as often.

-Air(space)craft are likely very limited in use since they must carry their own oxidizer.
-Artillery is godlike, almost unlimited range, highly accurate, and extremely lethal.
-Small arms have excellent range and accuracy, but will need bulky radiators to avoid overheating during sustained fire.
-Using normal weapon sights/scopes is difficult if not impossible due to bulky suits and helmets, you will most likely use some kind of sophisticated HUD in the suit helmet to aim with. -Shotguns and explosive/fragmentation weapons are highly effective.
-Heavier armor can be employed but even the smallest suit or habitat puncture could be lethal.
-Vehicles are be critical as on-foot EVAs will only be able to last a few hours before running out of power and life support.
-Night is 2 weeks long, extremely dark and cold.
-Networks of tunnels and underground facilities are critical, but vulnerable to siege.
-Whoever controls orbit wins in the long run.

>>56583588
I know you're hospital-based and what you say is correct for John Doe who has no ID on him and a GCS of 3 who comes in via ambulance after getting hit by a car, however it's a pretty mainstream thing within small units who work remotely to understand blood types and rhesus +ve/-ve so that the medic can transfuse blood directly from the appropriate member when evac is driving yourself hours to the nearest major trauma hospital. When you're guaranteed to go into a PEA arrest from hypovolemic shock and the other option is the potential for a hemolytic transfusion reaction because a patch wasn't right, you're going with the patch.

>>56622428
Type 1, good fucking luck, Ian McCollum.
Type 2/3 milled, Arsenal makes milled AKs, and there's receivers on the net for builds, the 3s are the predominate of the milled designs.
Type 4, the AKM, is what everyone sees when they talk about anything AK-47. Various flavors from around the second world.
AK-74, it's own separate thing, but some parts can interchange between the 7.62 and 5.45.
Notable mentions:
Type 56, Chinese stamped AK, borrows more from the milled AKs features than the AKM, because of the Sino-Soviet split.
Valmet, Finnish AK.
Galil, jew copy of the RK.
Yugo M70, slightly different from AKM design specs.
VZ-58, not an AK.

Other than it being an obvious joke post, in the russian mind there is no contradiction because they operate with a different definition of nazism than the west.

Whereas in the west, nazism is explicitly seen in the context of its political ideologies and manifestation (far right, hypernationalist, militaristic, fascist, totalitarian, antidemocratic, anti rule of law), in places like the Soviet Union, later Russia, declaring totalitarianism and similar shit bad when they themselves were pretty much just the left wing version of the same system wasn't a smart idea. The idea of nazism that developed over there was simply put "Anti-Russian".

Therefore, one could be a left wing homosexual liberal jew but if your politics aligned against Russia, Russians will see you as a "nazi" even if by western standards you are far from it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Previous >>56436159
Happy New Year Edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

I know people like to say that one shouldn’t try to save on NV and it’s better to save up some more, but why? Is the warranty actually desirable? Is nitrogen purging really worth the extra money? Maybe the warranty and purging are worth it in combination. Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56554244
>Is Superior Tactical legit?
Yes, they are recommend for people looking to buy individual tubes for self assembly of NVDs. You can sometimes find great deals from them on their ebay page.
>And if so, why shouldn’t I buy a tube and a parts kit from them and assemble it myself? Could save myself some dollars doing it that way.
You can save some bit of money, but not by much imo, like at max $500 if you really find a great deal on a tube with several blems or lower specs.
>Is nitrogen purging really worth the extra money?
Maybe not for you but for me I prefer it, but you can do the ghetto wine preservative or argon purging: https://youtu.be/vSumk0HeNqc?t=704
>Is the warranty actually desirable?
Most warranty by retailers are only on the housing for the 10 year they state they will cover. The tube is likely only covered by the OEM (L3 or Elbit or Photonis) warranty coverage, but one thing is most reputable retailers do not want to have a bad rep and will likely repair, fix, replace it under the warranty.

>>56554403
Getting dedicated binos will have one set of controls for power, gain (if available), lighter weight, have the ability to use battery power packs and the tubes will more likely to be in spec with each other and have better collimation.
Going with a newer tube down the line to pair with your current pvs-14 tube and getting a housing to fit the tubes may have some benefits, like using different housing like the Katanas for a lighter setup, you can go the route of two pvs-14 with a panobridge to get a pano setup or go with the RPNVG instead and get a much better pano setup but will not have the individual articulation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56577049
Streamlight's 18650 are protected 18650, the extra length is the circuitry that protects the battery from over charging and being used above it's limits to power something the extra circuitry is that USB charging port it's similar to the surefire 18650 batteries.
Look for any 18650 battery from Samsung, LG, Sony, Panasonic with no protection circuit and it'll probably fit just fine.
Here is a picture of some 18650 I had to modify or buy that were not protected for my Jerry-Ce5, the orange one is a cloud defensive 18650 (Sony vtc6) and the green one is a modified modlight 18650 (Keeppower but the OEM is LG) I stripped the protective circuit and it works like normal.

posts.com:
>>56596980
>under $1000
Opinions of a sometimes night hunter, this is going to come down to the experience you want to have/the ability your rifle has to support picatinny attachments.

Thermal option:
ATN THOR LT 160
Yes it is only a 160 x 120 Sensor, but it is 60hz and will be perfectly fine for rodent removal within rimfire ranges. No bells and whistles so no recording your hunts, fancy reticles, color palettes (White/Black hot only) or phone connectivity but it will get the job done. Funnily enough that simplicity helps you dodge the worst parts of ATN digital/thermal devices which are their buggy firmware and apps. It mounts in standard scope rings and since its thermal so you don't need any extra equipment beyond batteries. You'll be able to spot animals through light brush and in areas you can't easily illuminate, but you are going to have to get used to shooting at low res animal shaped blobs. As you get started, remember to glass targets for a bit to evaluate their movements to assist in identification.

Digital NV option:
Sightmark Wraith
Buddy's uncle has one that we've compared to his original gen 1 ATN X-Sight. The Sightmark is more compact, has a better viewfinder, and doesn't crash intermittently throughout the night. With an illuminator at rimfire ranges you will have a very good high res display almost like you would have through a traditional daytime scope, just black and white. You also get a built in recorder and daytime color image. Its picatinny mount only so you will need a top rail on your rifle, and you either piggyback the illuminator from it or you will need rail space on your rifle to mount one.

>>56608215
PVS-2 is Gen 1, and like all Gen 1 devices it can't turn off instantly. The reason for this is that it has an internal power supply (The source of the “ringggg” noise) that takes awhile to fully discharge. Depending on various factors this can literally take multiple minutes, during which time the tube itself remains powered even though you've turned the power off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56623505
It's a Perst 1 IR laser
Since I haven't seen anyone else post one I'll give a review for those interested although it may be pointless unless you can find a way to get Zenitco through customs now.

It's a full power laser with only 1 function, that being the IR laser itself. It has the standard perst controls (short tap for constant on, double tap for strobe, and hold for momentary) but uses a proprietary switch that is not compatible with other perst model (maybe they work with their klesch flashlights idk). Effectively it's like an sr01 but even smaller. Very easy to tape just about anywhere.

As it's full power only (no brightness adjustments) you get the classic laser beam effect. I'd actually rate this as a con because of its size and weight, it's intended for smg's and pistols so a FP beam actually blooms out your target and autogates your tubes at the ranges you'll be using it at.

The zeroing is aids and you'd better pray to whichever deity you prefer that you don't strip the 1.5metric hex screws which are used for zeroing- the same used to zero the perst 3 illuminator. There's no clicks and they strip if you breath on them. The upside is that they are $150 and Ivan accidentally sent me a free vis laser version too which now lives on my benelli m4

If I ever strip the screw to the point where I can no longer zero it I'm replacing it with a comparable holosun. Sometimes FP isn't what you need

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Over the years I've read multiple references to "duplex" loads, where two different kinds of powder are used in the same cartridge. For example:
-It is typical to add a very small amount of fast smokeless, or BP, to the case first before dropping the main charge for very large cartridges, i.e. elephant guns
-Apparently some muzzle-loading Schutzen rifles use a small amount of smokeless mixed with mostly BP, which apparently eliminates fouling.
-People trying to customize burn rates when the powder they need isn't available. Example, the original "triplex" load for .454 Casull.
I'm looking for reliable sources on any of this, not boomers ranting on forums. Anyone know any books which get into this?

Get manuals. IMHO it's honestly worth it to buy a couple of the books, they're not expensive and they are handy. If you'd rather go with electronic formats then those are fine too. Bullet makers and Powder makers both publish loading data too, and that is generally free. Consult both. Bullet makers will usually have data for their bullets with various brands of powder. And vice-versa, powder makers will have loads for various bullets all using their powder. Between the two you should be able to find the data for just about anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56607349
Duplex/triplex loads are a product of old technology. These days, powders are more uniform in burn rate and can achieve an exact desired effect with one, where old powders required a staged blend to get the burn rate just right.
t. Bought Ackley's book with .454 duplex loads and found that Accurate #9 or #7 was as good or better across the board

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56607349
>>56614709
I'll continue this by saying I can send over some pics of the original .454 load data from my book if you're interested. Biggest and most dangerous issue you may run into is that you HAVE to compress the load, because mixing the powders will make it wildly unpredictable. You're already in uncharted waters with duplex loads, since shit like Quickload will not be able to account for it. Trail Boss would be a good starting point if you want to experiment, because it's nearly impossible to overpressure unless you SUPER compress it.

>>56614700
If you happen to figure out the title of that book please share. I can share one: Shooting the British Double Rifle by Graeme Wright discusses two forms of duplex loads. The first is in the context of solving ignition problems and hangfires in very large cases by adding a few grains of fast powder next to the primer. The second is making modern BP "hotter" in order to make loads duplicating the factory originals which the rifle was regulated for since 19th century British BP was stronger than modern GOEX, Swiss, etc. In that case some % of the BP load was replaced with smokeless.

just to elaborate on the grappling:
Judo is a sport derived from Jujutsu, its focus is on throws and grapples to achieve this (dont think what I said about full contact doesn't apply to Judo because you are taking real falls in it) and that can make it a little dangerous to use in a fight since you may not necessarily want to crack your assailants head open on the sidewalk and render them a vegetable - courts do apply concepts of reasonable force
BJJ is a varient of Jujutsu that focuses on immediately taking your opponent down to the ground and choking them to submit, there are several reports of women who have trained in BJJ using it to stop rapists so I'd say that is the gold standard for proof of practicality I'd only suggest that going to the ground wouldn't be a good idea if facing multiple assailants since while you role with one the rest of them would be punching/kicking/clubbing/stabbing you

All we could get him to eat was some tuna-flavored tapioca paste that the vet would give him (it's only like 6 calories per tube, so not much), and he drank a small amount of water, but that was on the morning of the 2nd. He's just returned to laying under the table and taking nothing, he feels cold to the touch.
By all accounts, it seems like his liver is failing, and he's probably going to die. We're now looking at an in-home euthanasia service so he doesn't need to leave his home or his family. If the weather in the morning permits, I'm going to bring him outside to the back yard. It's only fair, he's wanted to go out there for the whole of his short little life, and we kept saying he could when he was a little bigger in the spring, lest an owl or hawk grab him. I think now is the time to grant that wish, he won't last that long unless a miracle happens. I don't think he would run if he wanted to anyway.
Thanks for the sympathy and support that you guys have given through this ordeal. I may try to post some videos I have of him later if it's alright. I'm currently posting from work, so when I finally post again it will probably be after he's gone. I'm going to spend what time I have left with the little guy, keeping him company and taking some final vids and pics so I can remember him.

>>56614972
Alright, last update. I took him outside a little before the vet came. He seemed a little confused. Sat with him a little before he decided he wanted to go back inside.
She came and confirmed that it was terminal, it was affecting his eyes and brain, and he was blind. His eyes were open, he just couldn't see anything, wasn't even blinking anymore.
We set him down on his favorite bed, the one he took over from the dogs. Put the bed in front of the Christmas tree, we didn't really have the time or thought to bother taking it down yet. She gave him the shot to put him under, startled him at first but then he began to calm down and go to sleep. We spoke to him and rang his bell as he drifted off (he used to ring a bell to get treats, even when he stopped eating he'd still ring it and purr). She made a few casts of his paw in clay as this happened.
She gave him the last shot after a little after that as we gathered around and patted him softly. He was gone in minutes.
We've all been crying, even before she got here we cried and sat around him. Even my normally stoic dad was bawling his eyes out so hard he was coughing, and this man didn't cry at his own mother's funeral.
I don't know what to do anymore, I feel empty inside. He won't be waiting for me at the bottom stair when I leave for work next weekend. He won't rush to the door to greet me when I come home, I'll never set his bell down for him to ring before he gets his favorite treats again, I'll never hear his sweet little voice call out to me again. I'd rather have died in his stead, he was only a baby. He was born in late summer, and he never lived to see the spring. I feel like I failed him.
I'm sorry there's not a happy end to this story guys. I'd have given anything to give him a few more years of life, I'd melt every gun I own in a huge fire and dump all my ammo in the sea if it meant he would have lived even a few more years. I can always buy more guns, I can't replace him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56615530
>I feel like I failed him.
You didn't. The day will come when you can accept that.

Something to consider, going into the future, not for anytime "too soon." I've buried about a dozen friends now, and these things helped out. Eventually.

You can honor the memory of your friend by adopting another who needs a home. There are millions, and you can give at least one a chance that they didn't have. It hurts, but they are also a comfort.

Something I learned was that a single cat gets a bit neglected, even in a house with best intentions. Humans just get wrapped up in things and distracted by Important Life Stuff. So, if you have the option, get more than one cat. Two works if that's already stretching your resources & space and you can still do it, but three seems to be an optimum. They have each other to explore & play and socialize with, humans present or not. They really are highly social, especially if their humans interact with them and show them how.

Two often work together, but the relationship can become one-sided. I've found that three create an unstable dynamic so that one doesn't dominate another & bully. No matter any conflict two get into, the third provides a distraction that breaks a pattern of regular abuse of one against another. You need to guide them, and be attentive should one personality just not work out for Reasons.

Anyway, the younger the better. They grow up as if they are brothers & sisters. How you teach them young will imprint for their entire lives, so put extra effort in early.

Cheers and good on ya' for having a huge heart. Peace to you and all of yours.

I believe that Germany could have been fine with an upgraded version of the panzer 3 (although at that point it would be a different tank).Panzer 4 makes no sense and panther comes too late to be perfected.A panzer 3 like tank with some very minor but necessary upgrades with the main hull shape being derived from the panzer 3 would do the trick.It would look like a more beefed Vk16.02 and be slightly wider and longer,or like a German t44 with a far roomier turret

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The designations are misleading. Pz.IV was ready in 1937. Pz.III only got into serial production by 1939 because of the suspension, considerations for large dcale production and all else Daimler Benz tried to do, whereas Krupp stuck to well established technology in its Pz.IV even against the wishes of army procurement. They arguably put their budget to better use too, opting against torsion bars that didn't offer real advantages over leaf springs yet to give the Pz.IV's turret an electric drive, which is a massive advantage in reaction time and gunnery over the Pz.III's hand crank.
That's however not to say that anyone could've had the foresight to cancel Pz.III. Tank and aircraft development was extremely chaotic in the 1930s. There constantly were new innovations in mechanical engineering that had to be integrated into a design in progress, which gets exponentially more difficult without CAD or any computers at all, unless slide rules count.
The army itself often couldn't accurately predict what it needed in the upcoming war. Future upgrades were barely considered in any design anywhere, unlike today.
If your tank development program is supposed to run from 1934 to 1938 under those circumstances without the benefit of hindsight, it's impossible to come up with a single type of tank that will remain competitive till 1945, even if Pz.IV got close.

The much bigger mistake than building both Pz.III and IV was that they didn't immediately try to narrow down what they actually needed from their tanks once real combat experience became available. They spent years sitting on their asses and then rushed Pz.V from a wet napkin drawing to field use in six months or less, with obvious issues.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56615817
>large dcal production
*scale
>What changed that?
Length of suspension travel and dampening among other things. Pz.III's torsion bars weren't set up to have much more travel than Pz.IV's leaf springs, and dampeners could only be afforded for the first and last wheels, whereas the friction between multiple leaf springs already functions as dampening to a sufficient degree for the low speeds possible with the engines and steering systems at the time.
High frequency oscillation problems in suspension systems weren't well understood at the time, and it wasn't until Panther that a durable suspension system with long travel and low unsprung mass became available.
Christie failed in regards to durability and unsprung mass, hence some of the faster Christie suspension tanks tended to destroy themselves, and provided poor ride quality that quickly tired the crew out.

Needlessly combining multiple companies into a single project, each with their own turf wars over patents and profits, is a dubious idea at best when you don't have the time to deal with legal or communication issues. Daimler-Benz's project management in particular was just awful. Aside from the absolute state of the Pz.III project compared to Krupp's Pz.IV, they didn't even manage to put their bid for Pz.V onto paper while M.A.N. already had everything on the way to production - and the final Panther was also much more than D.B.'s T-34 copy ever set out to do.
D.B. is moreover the only German aircraft engine manufacturer that never managed to make the jump from piston to jet engines.

In hindsight, best way to push Pz.III forward would've been to transfer the project from Daimler-Benz literally anyone else.

>>56619330
Of course each firm had different experience. In this particular instance, Daimler Benz was the first German firm to produce viable fighter engines after the first world war. They should've had some of the best expertise in aircraft engines, and they likely did. They even built a variable geometry supercharger for the 109's engine, which can continuously adjust its compresaion ratio without the losses and the bulk of conventional multi-ratio chargers, which then have to be throttled to compress air at a given altitude into the desired manifold pressure. You don't even see that in most sports cars these days.
Engine chargers were the starting point from which internal combustion based turbomachinery eventually developed into complete jet engines.

Despite this RLM repeatedly telegraphing their interest in jet engines, even cancelling and discontinuing piston projects toward the end, D.B. still lagged behind every other player in the industry.

A lack of expertise here, again, in their core business field, couldn't have been the issue. It was a missed opportunity that let them fall behind as they did, and one the RLM kept nagging every conceivable manufacturer about.
Thus it could've only been the kind of poor leadership that we consistently see from D.B. everywhere else.

You have to listen and think before you speak. Did you finish high school?

posts.com: Why was there never an SMG chambered in .357mag or other comparable cartridges? When the second World War started, it became clearer and clearer that common pistol calibers lacked the range, the stopping power and the penetrating power needed for a personal infantry firearm, and thus the concept of an assault rifle with intermediate rifle cardridge was born. But until the assault rifle was well established, wouldn't it had made sense to even experiment simply just making SMG:s more powerful? Danuvia M43 was the only example of something similar that i'm aware of and apparently it was well liked among the troops that used it, exactly for the reasons above, but other than that it seems that the thought never crossed anyone's mind.

>>56624005
Closest thing that did exist was the M2 Carbine (basically M1 with a fire selector and usually 30rd mags). 30 Carbine is roughly comparable to 357 Magnum, just slightly less mass and without the rim.

Before WW2 having a hybrid load out with SMGs/rifles covering each other and supporting/being supported by LMGs was considered adequate.
Beefing up an SMG to a magnum cartridge means either adding a locking system and therefore cost or a lot of bolt mass and immense recoil which makes hitting anything with it using bursts at medium ranges hard. M2 kind of worked out because we already had M1s and making them select fire was an easy enough modification, but by that time assault rifles were already a thing and did the same job better.

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist

>>56624688
It was really a further development of 7.63x25mm Mauser, which the Soviets really liked. They bought a fuckload of C96 pistols during the interwar years, with some seeing use as late as the Soviet Afghan War. When it came to developing a new pistol they naturally wanted it in a similar caliber, so much so that any 7.62x25 TT firearm can also fire 7.63x25mm Mauser as well.

It's a bit of a stretch to compare it to 357 Magnum owing to it's significantly lower bullet mass and slightly lower velocity. It's a solid pistol cartridge with a flat trajectory and excellent penetration though, so it has that going for it. I'd feel pretty confident being issued a PPS-43 in WW2.
>>56624814
It's pretty fast compared to 9mm or 45 ACP, but you are correct in that it's not 30 Carbine or 357 Magnum. It doesn't need a locked breech or a particularly fuck-massive bolt though.

Again, impressive cartridge but a stretch to compare it to 357.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When you blow up satellites they burst into large amounts of space debris that pose a hazard to other satellites and add new hazards of future launches to avoid.

Things in orbit are orbiting at a specific speed to retain their orbit. If they slow down or speed up their orbit changes. Violently blowing things up is going to put the pieces into several new orbits since the explosion force will increase and decrease the speed of the pieces relative to its former orbit.
Some of these crash into and destroy more things repeating the process.

Enough of this eventually makes use of satellites or space launches too difficult by creating an orbitting cloud of high speed particles.

They have a term for this.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56611449
>why weren't they replaced with bullpups, then?
Because many of those countries that made bullpups, gutted their defence industries after the Cold War. Weapons development for anything except ARs was basically put on the backburner since they saw no need for it.

This meant that bullpups didn't see much development after the CW, while ARs continued to develop. So when those countries started shopping for replacements, ARs were the sensible option.

Only now are bullpups starting to see development again. The newer ones (eg. VHS-2, X95) have been seeing good success, and have been adopted by a number of countries in the last 10 years. Expect to see more successes over the coming decades, as new bullpups spring up.

This article (https://special-ops.org/why-does-australia-use-steyr-aug-instead-m4/) has a few interesting statements regarding it but its hard to verify if its true since no source is given.
>at that time Colt had suffered a serious setback when it lost out to FN of Belgium for the manufacture & supply of M16A2 rifles to the US military. Colt reacted to this by stating that if Australia wanted the M16A2, we would have to buy it from Colt. However, the Australian government has long maintained the need for local production (for the sake of self-sufficiency in small arms supply) and decided if Colt was not willing to let us build it locally, we would select another manufacturer that would let us make it locally.
>Because, in 1985, the Australian Army did an extensive evaluation of the Steyr AUG A1 against the M16A2, and it won easily. In fact, there is a scanned copy of the original evaluation available online here (http://www.mediafire.com/file/r6xjht7gfczas1a/Australian_Army_AUG_Evaluation_Report_-_Complete%2C_OCR%27d.pdf/file). It concluded that “The results clearly demonstrated that from an engineering viewpoint the performance of the STEYR was significantly superior to the COLT in most respects; particularly in terms of endurance and adverse conditions.
>The Australian SASR and Special Forces refuse to use the Steyr and use the M4 instead. They say the gun is too difficult to use when wearing body armor, takes too long to reload under stress, and is too fragile for intense combat.

>>56623978
>adapt to and absorb its own contradictions
historically this just hasn't been the case, in fact not long after he made those predictions much of the world's wealth was literally blown up or starved between two global wars. capital has required direct assistance from the state simply to exist without crippling itself (and it's still very, very good at it) since the mercantilist era.

it's a lot less like capitalism absorbs its contradictions and a lot more like it's quite good at growing up among the rubble of its own cycles of destruction.

it keeps recovering not because it is inherently "correct" but because enough of it has survived its repeated cycles of collapse to prevent itself (sometimes - i.e. often - violently) from being unseated. the wealthy and powerful like staying that way. they need state support to do it - hence the opportunistic use of Cold War propaganda to suppress leftist or even vaguely anti-corporate political ideologies as "doomed and wrong" while repeatedly subjecting the populace to ever more dangerous catastrophes in the name of cost-cut efficiency for wealth accumulation.

it genuinely just hasn't gotten as bad as Marx was expecting it to... yet. given the frequency of destabilization in capitalist societies (bear in mind that Russia of today is essentially the neoliberal/neoconservative endgame on fast-forward since 1991), i remain unconvinced that there is something inherently immunizing to capitalism that will prevent an unrecoverable collapse - and it would be far from the first time wealth inequality had strained a society past its breaking point and killed it for good. it'd just be the first time the breaking society was arguably global in reach

>>56624264
that's a fair criticism. i'm treating capital here as the higher wealth holders as a demographic, and the state as the direct operators of enforcement capacities - in an autocracy these are basically the same, in an oligarchic system my argument is their frequent cross-pollination leads to many of the same failings

in that sense, i guess it's not right to call Russia's system "fast forward" - more like "skipping to the end of where i think wealth inequality coupled with the accelerating effect of existing wealth is inevitably going to lead to". it's easy to ignore the pattern by citing individual causes, but the underlying "wealth concentration creating inequality that stresses the unwritten rules of society + capitalism lacking mechanisms to control that without nominally anti-capitalist state intervention" is something of a throughline historically.

maybe that's not something inherent to capitalism per se, just any centralized, hierarchical, inflexible power structure - but i'd argue that capitalism left to its own devices lends itself to that power structure because of its provable tendency towards monopolization and suppression of competition (innovation is only selected by the profit optimization function if it has the highest ROI between strategies which include market cornering, cost cutting, price manipulation, etc. - none of which support much R&D spending)

Do yourself a favor and only buy the 4.5" Fullsize model. It is the most pleasant shooting barrel length and the ergos on the fullsize frame are far far better than the compact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't live in NY, but I have an SCR. Mine was used and has a (shitty) diy upper from the previous owner. Things to know:
>ar style charging handle is goofy with the traditional stock
>mag release ergos are a little weird
>because of the way the lower works, you can't just undo the rear pin for cleaning. You have to fully separate the upper and lower or it won't go back together correctly.
>lack of any muzzle device (like mine) will make it bright and loud as hell. People often assume it's not 5.56 at the range
>factory LOP is a bit short IMO, you may consider a pad to lengthen it
>relating to the above, always do your research on aftermarket parts to ensure compatibility. Remember that you won't be able to change your recoil spring like you would on a normal ar if you decide to change your gas system.
>mine is a picky eater, but that might be because the upper was built by a tard.

>>56621824
You've got some good responses so far to research. What you also need to do is match the weapon(s) to the person(s). Develop a personality profile. What is their knowledge base, what are their personality quirks? Etc.

Some guy who just came back from WWI with a 1911 he "acquired" would have a reason for using that gun, including training, knowledge, familiarity, comfort, combat experience, etc. He would know exactly what ammo to use for what task, have a cleaning & maintenance kit, proper carry rig. He could pick up almost any handgun at random and immediately use it.

Some guy living in Chicago might pick up a .38 revolver, maybe even off a dead cop if the opportunity were available to him. It might be a .32 that breaks at the top for reloading (my grandfather had one, small & cool, but underpowered). He might have nearly zero-knowledge of the weapon & how to use it and care for it and be safe with it. He might just throw it into his jacket pocket with some loose rounds for a reload as a security blanket and not even know he has to wipe & oil it down to prevent it from rusting. He might pick up a 1911 and not know how to seat the magazine or rack the slide.

Keep these factors in mind. You're not just doing a period piece here, you have to match personality & opportunity between characters & their weapons ... either of choice or necessity.

> t. I've done a bit of writing over the years. This shit's important for immersion.

I can't vouch for the accuracy of the Wikipedia page, so do more research and don't buy a 70s Model 10 (or worse, a modern hillary hole lock model) to pass off as an M&P or a 1899 Hand Ejector, but a Model 10 was one of my first thoughts.
>In 1899, the United States Army and Navy placed orders with Smith & Wesson for two to three thousand Model 1899 Hand Ejector revolvers chambered for the M1892 .38 Long Colt U.S. Service Cartridge. With this order, the Hand Ejector Model became known as the .38 Military and Police model. That same year, in response to reports from military sources serving in the Philippines on the relative ineffectiveness of the new cartridge, Smith & Wesson began offering the Military & Police in a new chambering, .38 S&W Special (a.k.a. .38 Special), a slightly elongated version of the .38 Long Colt cartridge with greater bullet weight (158 grains) and powder charge increased from 18 to 21 grains of gunpowder.
>In 1902, the .38 Military & Police (2nd Model) was introduced and featured substantial changes. These included major modification and simplification of the internal lockwork and the addition of a locking underlug on the barrel to engage the previously free-standing ejector rod. Barrel lengths were 4-, 5-, 6-, and 6.5-inches with a rounded butt. Serial numbers for the Military & Police ranged from number 1 in the series to 20,975. Most of the early M&P revolvers chambered in .38 Special appear to have been sold to the civilian market. By 1904, S&W was offering the .38 M&P with a rounded or square butt, and 4-, 5-, and 6.5-inch barrels.

>>56621824 (You) (Mother) (Fucker)
You struck gold with this thread. You better have the decency to save it all and study it carefully.

There's a lot of info missing for context, but I'll suggest a couple of main forks you need to make decisions on. Decide if your story involves American guns or European guns, or both. You'll need to explain (by example in-plot) why. How prominently do guns feature as integral to the plot? If you're considering a 100 minute movie, how many minutes of screen time will each weapon see? This will help determine how much thought & research needs to go into each weapon & character wielding it.

When did the guns originate from? Will they be mostly WWI surplus? Will they be largely civilian models from the era? Will they be new (manufactured ~1920) or older, used? Because, you might be looking at what was commonly available during the 1890s. In 1920 Mexico, there may be surplus guns (and ammo) from several wars (around the world) conducted during the 1890s and up to about WWI.

Did the hero bring his own gun(s) to Mexico? Or did he make do with what he found when he got there? This will determine likely availability both for the hero and other characters. The question will also apply to long guns that may make appearances.

For one example of many possibilities, a fairly "modern" cartridge designed for revolvers in 1907 is the .44 Special (by Smith & Wesson). It's an ideal dick-swinging cartridge for 1920, like a .44 mag or a .454 today. It would have been a powerful, designed specifically for smokeless powder:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.44_Special

Other legacy cartridges prior to the turn of the century either still used black powder or used smokeless powder poorly. Note that by 1920, there would still be people using black powder firearms, so other characters in the movie might be shooting those, especially in Mexico, which can lead to some impressive cinematography when 4 or 5 people light of six or ten rounds each.

>>56621824
It's not really the exciting answer, but Colt 1911. If you want to make it more interesting, a 38 Super version. 9rds standard magazine capacity and it's a pretty zippy caliber.
>>56621878
There really wasn't much viable competition at the time.
>C96
Overly complicated. Ergonomics really aren't very good. Slow to reload. Very high velocity cartridge, but overall not worth it.
>Luger
Very cool looking and feels great, pretty good reliability if kept clean, but still more complicated and finicky than a 1911. The lack of a slide release lever makes unloading or clearing jams tricky as well. Toggle is difficult to grab and cycle, safety is backwards.
>Astra 400
Wants to fly out of your hands and is generally miserable to use. Does work, but hitting anything with it is a challenge. This goes for most blowback pistols scaled up to a caliber in the 9x19/45ACP power factor range.
>Small 380/32 ACP pistols
These might make sense due to at least being smaller and concealable. Colt 1903 stands out. But now you're dealing with low magazine capacity and power factor.
Savage 1907 is an interesting choice with a 10rd double stack magazine.

>Revolvers
Downsides of revolvers as a whole. Low magazine capacity and slow reloads. Plus if we're talking gate loaded design which was still common at the time (Nagant for instance) these reloads were glacial. Effectively something that just isn't going to happen in combat.
The upside with revolvers has traditionally been power, but back in the 1920s that wasn't necessarily the case yet. We didn't get 357 Magnum until the 1930s. Until then we had stuff like 38 Special which is vaguely comparable to 9x19mm (if that, often loaded closer to 380 ACP) and 45LC or 455 Webley which were comparable to 45 ACP (even then 455 is colder).

Best you could do would be like a S&W hand ejector or Colt Positive in 38 Special. Fairly small, easy enough to reload, 6 shot and an acceptable cartridge. Overall still inferior to the 1911 though.

>>56576067
The "eye of the needle" being a gate doesn't change the meaning much at all. The gate referred to was a small gate found on the walls of fortified Israelite cities. The gate was so small that animals couldn't fit through and people could only fit if they abandoned their bags and large possessions outside. The purpose of the gate was to allow people to come and go even when all the larger entrances were shut for security reasons. The idea being that any would be attackers would be forced to enter single file without shields or spears.

So the meaning is still "you must abandon your worldly possessions to enter the Kingdom of Heaven.

It's much different, because first and foremost we are not worshipping the Saints. Secondly, while it is true and a decent point to make that the golden calf was not actually an idol to Baal as many erroneously claim but actually meant as an idol to the Lord, being represented by the calf for his strength, I think it's safe to say that having an image of the real God of man Jesus Christ isn't in violation of that statute. When that commandment was written, God was unknowable to men, it being said that gazing upon his true form would kill a man, or make him burst into flames. God to them had no form and was not to be represented by any of them. Jesus, however, was God made flesh, therefore God had a form.
You could argue that the lamb imagery is closer to the calf though, given that it's another animal representation of God. However, Jesus, the Apostles, and the author of Revelations also referred to Christ as the lamb of God, being the everlasting sacrifice for our sins, and in Revelations the visions of Christ that were written down had him depicted as a lamb at times, so it's not totally erroneous and we aren't worshipping golden idols of a lamb either way so I think it's fine.

>>56616363
very hard. it's not just "grow some mold", you first have to idenitify what mold to grow, then you have to grow it in sterile conditions so there aren't other kinds of molds, bacteria, etc, in it. And then you have to extract the useful drug from the mold. You also need to make a LOT of it since penecillin is very quickly eliminated by the kidneys. Back in the early days like the late 1940's, they'd actually collect a patient's piss so they could extract and re-use the penicillin from it, that was because it was so hard and so expensive to make even then.

Morse code would be a useful thing to bring back, being compatible with signal fires, bells, and so on, not to mention that with English being a direct descendant of Latin the modern Morse code will be compatible.
I'd also like to mention the concept of the optical telegraph, a series of towers with arms that could denoted a character which would be repeated by each tower until the message arrived at its destination. It's no more complicated than a windmill and would be perfectly practical to build.
The first successful model was invented in France in 1792. It was good enough that it could send a message of 36 symbols across 230km in about 30 minutes. That was insane even for its day and would be invaluable for the Romans who needed to keep an empire together.

Having seen a lot of zombie movies, especially Dawn of the Dead and the remake, the way I would do it is a big double-bricked or even triple-bricked house with a courtyard in the middle instead of a backyard. First floor would be two storey high, no windows facing outside on the first storey -- only doors and windows facing courtyard. Door to outside would be set on the second storey with a retractable staircase down. With no windows or door facing outside eon the first storey, it's just a thick brick wall facing outside -- fire resistant. Shape of the building should be cylinder, as round and smooth possible exterior wall first floor s it's hard to climb and hard to push over.

The courtyard would have different fruit trees, the three sisters corn, bean, and squash. Chickens, ducks, and goats. The rooftop would be used to collect rain and grow more food in containers since there will be more sun. Staircase and handhold would be build into the inner brickwalls all around the courtyard so there is no chance of accidentally being trapped if the door locked. I would have little fruit tree bonsai inside the house and on the roof for fun and just in case the trees in the yard die.

Beside the usual supplies, plan for a period of limited electricity. Look to Ukraine. Access to power comes and goes, fuel and gas is a limited commodity. You can't rely on either for food making, running heaters or much else. Basically your tv, kitchen appliances, water heater, fridge, freezer, laptop are all going out for time unknown. Your best bet is to rely on low power equipment. Radio, hand set, cell phone, tablet, you can run those for a long time if you have access to rechargeable batteries and occasional power. Gas boxes, ethanol, a few cans of fuel, or kerosene, and the appropriate stoves will let you make warm food when you want it. Still you should learn to make food without heating.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56618918
>5 shot
>a good do-everything gun
>Mostly would be for target shooting
No.

If you want a concealable carry weapon for self-defense, compromising with a 5-shit & short barrel to get a compact, subtle package is reasonable. .357 is wasted out of such a compact weapon, although a gun designed for .357 will digest .38 Spl P+ and/or might have a 9mm conversion which would also handle P+ easily.

But, "do-everything" for "mostly target shooting" largely negate that consideration. Especially in .357 mag, which really only starts to shine when the barrel is 3" minimum or (much better) 4" & up to about 6-ish. That's a full-size weapon, you want 6 shots (or 7 or 8) in a revolver. Now you have a home defense weapon plus a great plinker & target shooter & hunting weapon. You can plink .38 out of it all day and keep .357 in reserve for defense/hunting.

If you want a target shooter that can also do "other things," try to find something in a 4" or 4 1/2" barrel to get .357-worthy performance out of it. If you drop down to 3 1/2" or under, you're getting a lot of flash & bang out of it but actual ballistics are marginally better than 9mm out of a semi-auto (9mm out of a revolver will be gimped by the cylinder gap, thus the P+ capability if you need self-defense).

My personal preference is solid stainless steel for a .357 mag. It will last forever. So, for durability & corrosion resistance, give that some thought. Blued carbon steel needs care & maintenance to retain aesthetics & value, brushed nickel has a nice aesthetic, but might as well go for stainless at that point since it's nearly the same and more durable.

You can also look to guns that you can swap barrels, which gives you a 2" snubby w/ .38 option for SD, but you can configure a 5" on there and kill beer cans w/ .357 at 50 meters. Or deer. Now we're talking "a good do-everything gun."

Why do you want a revolver? Just curious. I prefer them myself, but it's not always the best option for "everything."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56618918
The Model 60 Pro was my first revolver (though I I paid $760 for mine, but then again it was the mid-2010s). It's a great gun and if you're getting a Model 60 then you should definitely shell out for the Pro. The adjustable sights and nicer trigger are well worth it.
The only downside to the Pro is that (as far as I could tell) no one on Earth sells an off-the-shelf holster of any type for it. So you should expect to have to get a custom one made, though those can be surprisingly inexpensive. There's people on Etsy who make custom Kydex holsters for well, well under $100.
Whether the Model 60 Pro is worth the price depends on two questions. Can you afford it? And is there another gun that has all the features you want?
As for my advice, it's cheaper to buy something expensive than to buy something cheap, realize it doesn't do what you want, and then have to buy the expensive thing too. My experience is that going the cheap route when it comes to tools, camping equipment, and guns is generally a false economy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Best coming through:

WW1:
Storms of Steel - Ernst Jünger (obvious classic)
Dance of death at Col di Lana - Erik Durschmied (Tirolan farmers fending off the invading Italian bersaglieri and alpini)
The Good Soldier Švejk - Jaroslav Hašek (Comedic novel about a czech infantryman getting into loads of trouble)
The 7 Pillars of Wisdom - T.E. Lawrence (obvious classic, detailing about how WW1 was fought in the arabic lands)
Memoirs of a british Agent - R.H. Bruce Lockhart (British agent in Czarist russia right at the time WW1 happened and the Czar got thrown over)

WW2:
Mr. Brown - Jean Zumbach (Absolute Madlad from poland who flew for the R.A.F. and did a whole bunch of stuff)
Unknown Soldier - V. Linna (The War in Karelia against the soviets (after the first winterwar))

Misc:
African Games - Ernst Jünger (about running away at 16 to join french foreign legion)
Mr. Brown - Jean Zumbach (after ww2 he smuggled watches and later fought in Katanga AND Biafra, an absolute MADLAD )
The Naked and the dead - Norman Mailer (Pacific war)
Up Periscope - Robb White (Pacific war)
