posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56577285
It's not the worst possible option.
There are a lot of factors for what makes a good beginner gun. In this case,
>Mild recoil.
Check.
>Common and relatively affordable caliber.
Check.
>Common and affordable magazines.
Check.
>Easy to mount and use common accessories.
Mostly check. At least it has a picatinny rail on top and mounting points all over the handguard.

It is an expensive rifle and because it's an uncommon design things like spare parts will be hard to come by, particularly if they are discontinued later on. It's a pretty ergonomic design though and has a lot of little things going for it beyond the more major ones mentioned above.
>>56577316
Well no. It's exponentially more money, which means it's a bigger loss and harder to replace if something catastrophically bad happens.
The more significant downside is spare parts aren't going to be as available as they are for a standard AR-15. That's only an issue if you really need them, but if you shoot enough sooner or later something breaks. That's fine as long as SAI is still in business and still supports this particular rifle, which will probably be true for the short term future, but it's hard to say if the same will be true 10 years from now. Suppose the VHS is no longer made, or Springfield no longer exists, or it is still available but there has been a design change and the firing pins for the new model aren't backwards compatible with yours. That's not a problem you need to worry about with a regular AR-15.

Of course that doesn't mean no fun allowed and nobody should ever buy anything but an AR-15, but it should be a factor that is taken into consideration. If OP really really likes the VHS and that's what gets him excited to own a gun he should buy it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56577285
While I did try a few ARs and had traditional rifles as a kid, my very first semiauto rifle of my own was a bullpup (though not that one). I don't regret it at all, it's a great layout, and in fact there are reasonable arguments that doing it as a first is better not worse. A lot of the complaints you see about modern ones (early ones did have bad triggers and such, took time to refine them, but same can be said about traditional layout guns too) come down to people having tons of muscle memory/practice/comfort with ARs. But if you're new you've got none of that. Good bullpups won't have issues with reloads or whatever if you've actually equivalently trained with them. And you will be able to move between bullpups relatively easily too, so not like you've got no variety if you want something else.

The downsides as people have said are that there is a much higher price floor (not that you can't spend even more on ARs, but you can get decent ones for much less), there is a smaller aftermarket (which may or may not matter to you), more limited servicing (so make sure there is a decent warranty) etc. They are on average all heavier, albeit with weight farther back towards your body which can make that weight feel better and be easier to control in use. But weight is weight if you plan to do outdoors trips.

If you can afford it though go for it. Make sure to test it thoroughly right away. And then practice. Like any reasonably quality gun, the limiting factor is going to be YOU for a long time. I would suggest being cautious about splerging on accessories however for a while.

As an richfag who owns more guns than he shoots, let me say this; If you buy a gun that YOU like, for whatever reason, be it unique, meme, movie/video game gun, if it's something you really like you will:
>want to learn more about it, becoming more knowledgeable about guns in general
>take good care of it, becoming more knowledgeable about the specific gun and proper gun care
>shoot it more often, making you a better overall shot and familiar with its pros and cons

I've owned literally dozens of guns and the two guns that really clicked for me were a SW 686+ and a Steyr AUG. I've learned more, shot more, went to competitions, and met new friends just because I bought a couple guns I really liked rather than one of my "everyone should own one of these" guns that sits in my safe.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56619039
Berdan primers have two holes on the sides instead of one hole in the center for the flash to go, can't poke it out with your resizing and depriming die and you can't really buy berdan primers in the US to reload it with so you have to blow it out with air/water then carefully drill a new center hole. Steel cased ammo is usually berdan primed plus steel doesn't deform easily like brass does so you can't really re-form it after it's been fired. Steel cased ammo also usually has a steel jacketed bullet which causes sparks and is therefore banned at many shitty public indoor ranges like OP is going to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56620247
>Is the range guy selling these to reloaders or reloading themselves or is it just straight to metal recyclers?
Yes.

Think it through for a minute. If you were running a range, collecting the premium cases and setting up several reloaders would generate a huge profit. You're buying bulk reloading supplies at bulk/wholesale prices, converting them into finished product with free, basically fresh brass, then selling at retail prices. Undercut whatever the local rate is by a couple of pennies and most people will just buy whatever is on the shelf. Anyone not buying your in-store reloads is bringing you more free brass.

Any cases not interesting to you personally, sell them off to reloaders. Anything not saleable, recycle for bulk metal prices. You have now collected All Of The Brass, and every point of value is stripped from it to support your business.

Is there anything wrong with the above? No.

However, the rules you put in place and enforce can be very debatable. Forcing people to leave their brass is the real issue here. If you run your business fairly so that your customers can keep their own brass if they wish to, you're doing nothing wrong & you acquire a loyal & happy customer base.

Steal their property from them and then charge $50 an hour range time on top of that ... You made some shitty business decisions and deserve to have your business go bankrupt.

>>56604112
I feel like this rifle would be popular in England or Australia

Also Tombstone is kind of neat, I stop by occasionally if I am going to the Cochise Stronghold. I don't think there's enough there to book a vacation but if you're in the area it is worth visiting.

The Tombstone Courthouse is a cool museum

The "Largest Rosebush in the World" is actually cool, it's grown on a trellis over a large courtyard, and one of the members of that family was a member of the Doolittle Raid, so they actually cover a bit of that as well, and the rest of it looks at Tombstone's economic history from the perspective of a wealthy family

The bus/carriage tours are neat

The mine tour is neat, the mine is really cool

The Okay Corral has its moments, the reenactment show is like, just okay but they have a bunch of really interesting photographs since part of the complex was a photostudio adjacent to the corral itself

the tourist trap souvenier shops are fine if you like americana/southwest art, the western wear stores aren't overpriced compared to what you'd find in Tucson.

The Crystal Palace is an okay restaurant, the waitresses dress like whores so that's pretty great. I think I had a taco pizza there that didn't give me food poisoning

The photo studios are kind of groaty because it's a pile of old cowboy costumes that have been worn by a million other people.

There's a few "haunted house" style attractions, they're kind of fun, and the Bird Cage Theater treads the line between one such attraction and a legitimate museum, it is probably the only one worth the cost of admission

I haven't done any of the shooting galleries because I have my own guns.

If you are in the Tombstone Area, the Council Rocks at Cochise Stronghold are worth a visit if you like Indian wars, and you can also visit Bisbee. Bisbee is an old copper mining town that was taken over by hippies who are now mostly all retired old people. It has a really big hole called the Lavender Pit.

>>56605848
It's actually pretty simple. Unlike silver and gold mines, which live and die on a boom and bust cycle, Copper mines provide a solid income stream for decades, and copper miners are comparatively very well paid. This means that the towns that grow up around them are relatively affluent and the actual buildings and physical infrastructure are very good. (in contrast to silver mines like Tombstone which are basically glorified shanties). All that is to say that the towns themselves are beautiful.

Once the mines shut down, all the miners move away, and the real estate market crashes because the town is in bumfuck nowhere. So the hippies, who don't care about jobs because they have rich parents, buy up these beautiful houses and historic buildings for like a dollar a pop and start art colonies. Later, retired hippies move in because their friends live there.

>>56619745
It's heavy for what it does. It could not be reliably synchronized to fire through a propeller without absymal fire rates, neccesating wing mounts which are inaccurate except for a narrow range you make the firing lines from the wing intersect like an X. It had no explosive filler and it actually was kinetically slightly overkill - meaning that to penetrate an usual plane armour plate a smaller rounds like the German 13mm could be even lighter for the same sized hole.

The own US navy estimated that a .50 weighs half a 20mm yet hits like a third of a 20mm.

So if you pull the .50s you could use the weight for more firepower (a Thunderbolt with 8 .50 would hit like 12 .50 if armed with 4 20mm for the same weight like the Bong Typhoons), or carry more fuel and ammo to protect the bombers longer, or carry harder hitting weaponry for more kills, or simply be lighter for better speed and agility in offense and defense.

American planes powered through by being fat (38 and 47), carrying a fat motor gun (39) and in case of the 40 and 51 just had to live with slightly armament and be lucky that there wasn't any well armoured axis bombers significant numbers. The 40 was a known dog, the 51 got saved by Bong engine.

>>56619921
50 cal damage mechanism is through spalling on impact with structural components, causing a nasty damage cone rather than the shallow (but still lethal) damage against spars. The rate of fire from having more numerous guns allowed for a denser volume of fire and higher probability of hit. Additionally it was more than an overmatch to pierce armor plates after making it through the fuselage, structure and components to kill the pilots. In contrast 20mm mineshells can and would make neat small fist sized holes and blow the skin apart, not to discount 20mm APHE however.

The .50 in the air was the right choice for the US at the time.
Germany had to worry about bombers so they used a lot of 20 and 30mm
The UK had to worry about much smaller German bombers so they used 20mm
The US had to protect their own bombers from small nimble fighters over long missions so they used .50

Basically everyone used more or less what made the most sense for their needs at the time by the end of the war

Abused SKS edition.
Previous: >>54962167 (4 months ago)

What have you been you working on, anons? Been far too long since the last thread. Got this /26\ SKS which was covered in cosmoline and the trigger was seized; seems the sear was rusted in place. Pull is heavy but smooth after cleaning. Safety spring snapped so it flops around and is taped in the "off" position until a spring comes in or I find one. So much cosmoline was in the barrel that I was able to save a .30" by 2.5" slug of it. A good reminder to swab barrels of surplus squeaky clean before shooting. Only thing left to do is clean the chamber which I'm about to do now; not sure if it's cosmoline globs or rust and I'm not too excited to find out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bottom of sear block. This is rusty cosmoline or grease; the side of it was stuck as it received no oil, grease, or cosmoline, so it rusted shut. Took a lot of PB Blaster, some heat (normal lighter cranked up to give a ~3" flame for a couple seconds), time, and a couple bumps to free it. Eventually freed it by trying to drop the hammer while the trigger group was removed from the rifle. Didn't put a ton of force on the trigger but just kept doing it. Eventually, bubbles of air came out from the oil in the little viewing window in the side of the trigger group which let me know the sear was moving somewhere. Took probably 3 hours on and off just doing that every couple minutes after the initial attempt mentioned earlier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And under the sear, man was that bad, just like this picture. No wonder it wouldn't move. There was a ton of random shit in here; huge chunks of god-knows-what came out of the whole trigger group, including, somehow, up behind the trigger. Quick tip if you need to drive in or remove the pin in front of the sear: the hammer is a similar width to the channel here. Use it as a wedge or block to prevent bending those "ears" or snapping them off.

I saved myself some trouble unknowingly as I had bought a Chinese SKS cleaning kit in the past. I had thought it was an AK cleaning kit (bought it without researching due to how cheap it was) and ended up needing it. The punch in the kit came in handy since I had no punches that skinny, only large ones which had previously been pointed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: All this and more was under the sear and under the thin trigger bar. How none of this grease even touched the sear's rails/sides (which caused it to rust and seize) I will never know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
have a browning recoilless. Browning states that it is not user-serviceable, please do not disassemble!
Well they're wrong, it's pretty easy to take apart. Replacing the annihilated old neoprene buffer and giving it all a good greasing.
It's a wacky shotgun, has an inner receiver mated to the barrel and outer receiver. Inner receiver has a multi-lug bolt-action action; it's a single shot. The inner receiver and barrel are held under spring tension by the sear. When the trigger is pulled, the inner receiver flies forward in the outer receiver, while holding the striker back. Once the barrel has flown forward a good 2", the striker is released and the 12ga is fired. The inner receiver then cocks itself back due to the recoil forces.

Makes the 12ga feel like a .410 no joke, it's crazy. Lock time is a good 1/8 of a second? Will need to get high speed video of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56600142
Very light use of #0000 steel wool. Minimal pressure, if basically any, will remove any fine rust on it. I recommend removing it from its stock to remove any rust forming under the stock before starting gently scrubbing/rubbing it with steel wool; for good instructions for disassembly, search "[gun model] disassembly" on YouTube and use a bit set for screwdrivers. Do not use chisel ground flathead screwdrivers. I like PB Blaster for oil, but any oil, gun or not, should work fine. I also use mineral oil (motor oil aisle, "30 weight lubricating oil", Walmart). Oil and a paper towel will remove any rust left behind. Don't go full retard and use something like (Boiled) Linseed Oil, a wood finish (it was used on metal, but that's for another time). Remember to remove any little fuzz left by steel wool; it can rust easily once oil dries or seeps out or scratch moving surfaces.

Only image I could find to show the difference in screwdrivers. Basically any bit set will have hollow ground flat head bits. Most screwdriver sets (with non-replaceable head) will have flat or chisel ground.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56600522
Oh yeah and keep the oil off the wood! Nothing worse than snapping a stock because of it sucking up oil! If you oil metal, such as the barrel, wipe it on, then wipe it right off. It will leave a thin film which protects the metal. For the side plates, butt plate, stock takedown, trigger guard, hammers, etc., take them off before cleaning and oiling, and then wipe off oil before reinstalling. Seems counterintuitive, but there's oil on the metal you can't see or feel. Any more than that and it'd either be slippery or soak into your wood stock and darken it. And getting oil soaked stocks fixed, whether they're broken or not, isn't cheap AFAIK.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56600522
And btw steel wool is only for removing rust or extremely stubborn dirt. Don't use it for regular cleaning! And since you're new, I'll remind you to remember to clean black powder fowling with hot water and Dawn after shooting (the day of), then dry fully and oil. I'm not a black powder shooter but I know that shit is super corrosive. Though IIRC a lot of modern alternatives may not be corrosive, or as corrosive. By "corrosive", I mean leaving behind salts IIRC. Also don't leave it loaded or your chamber may start to get pitted due to the powder soaking up moisture from the air. Also remember to not leave an air gap between powder and bullet when ramming; AFAIK BP builds up a ton of pressure when you do that and it can lead to a kaboom.

...and I think that's about all my knowledge of black powder.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56601424
>newbie retemper
Hellllllllll no. That is a "man with an expensive elecrtic kiln who knows what temperature to temper it at and how long" and "man who knows how to prevent scale buildup" (IIRC some kind of thick foil wrap over the object, to the point it's almost sheetmetal, with paper inside to burn up any oxygen inside) type project.
>weld to build up cylinder wall
Also newbie welding will probably be porous AFAIK which is not good in a cylinder. If it shoots fine, is in time, and isn't so thin it's unsafe, leave the cylinder alone.
>crack
Don't use that chamber, probably leaning towards don't use that cylinder.

I would highly recommend you buy something that isn't a revolver for learning; they're much more complicated than most other guns since each chamber could be timed different and each has to be checked for safe alignment to make sure it's not shooting out of time. The bolt (which locks into the cylinder on the side, usually a rounded nub with flat sides, often in the bottom of the cutout for the cylinder in the frame) also needs to consistently fall into its groove and lock securely enough in the revolver that there's not much play. I can't give too much other useful info; I'd link a Mark Novak video but it seems to have been deleted in his channel move, something that continues to piss me off since half of them WERE reuploaded and they were fine as-is when simply unlisted.

If a revolver is designed to take 9mm from the ground up, you'd need some way to stretch the cylinder and the entire frame to accomodate ... plus, it would have to have been designed to handle at least the equivalent of 9mm +P+ before any conversion attempt.

So, I'm going to say "Qualified: No."

However, Chiappa may have already considered all this from the beginning and they might have at least some sort of solution for some models. It's possible that any 9mm Chiappas they sell are already based on the .357, just configured for 9mm awaiting the day it can be converted.

While I might look into that if I wanted to try it myself, I'd probably just buy the .357 mag from the beginning and down-convert it to 9mm when I had funds available to acquire all the parts to do so. Instead of fucking around trying to jury-rig an abortion that will probably blow up in my hand, I'd invest in a .357/.38 with a couple barrel options & keep 9mm as a "maybe for the future" option. Which would also mean 9mm P+ & +P+ would be perfectly safe for maximum options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56573180
I didn't mean to imply there was something wrong with it. The point is that all parts have some kind of tolerance. For an easy to explain example, take the length of the barrel. Let's say it's supposed to be 5 inches. None of the barrels will be exactly 5.0000000 inches on the dot. some will be 4.95, some will be 5.01, and so on. The same thing applies to how straight the bore of the barrel is machined relative to the rest of it. It's supposed to be perfectly straight, but again in real life nothing is ever perfect, and one barrel might be .001 degrees to the left, the next might be .01 degrees up and .005 right, the next might be .01 left and .1 down, and so on. That's why guns have adjustable sights, so you can adjust them to account for all those production imperfections. You know the two barrels you have are different from each other, but nothing you wrote so far suggests that one of them is "not seated right". It is normal and expected for the POI to change if you swap barrels in a pistol. You should only worry about this if there's some other cause for concern, like the POI change was very significant, or you have some other reason to suspect something isn't right.

Okay, now the problem is my safety spring is snapped at the first bend, "fork" end. That is likely why my hammer won't drop, and wouldn't even when I first got it. Problem is, you have to drop the hammer to disassemble the trigger group and put a new safety spring in. What the fuck do I do? No one disassembles it without doing that. Can you fire an SKS without the safety spring?

PS: Solution to disassembly of rifle was easy; press down on button with muzzle to floor (magwell up/away from you), wait until receiver pops out of the stock a little. Pry under the back of the receiver with an old rounded off flathead gently. Do so until the disassembly button is no longer popping back into place with a tap or bump of the gun (no more than a half inch gap at most). Use a small rubber mallet to smack one side of the trigger guard gently; do it too hard and you'll probably split the wood. Repeat on other (left and right side of trigger guard). Do so back and forth until it starts wiggling its way loose (pry on it to check every couple taps). Seems rust and grease glued it in place.

They run maybe 20-50 yards before they fall, but that distance can be devastating when in brush and hills for recovery. .223 will make recovery easier. At least that's what I've scrounged up so far regarding calibers for hunting them; I haven't gotten a fox to sit still long enough to take a shot. If you took a headshot it wouldn't matter though, no doubt.

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56590824
CLPs usually aren't that strong as a solvent. My go-to is to have a dedicated solvent like Hoppes #9 for scrubbing off residue like carbon fouling and a CLP for lubricant/protective oil coat. If you think it's a scam product whatever, but they aren't expensive or anything.

For cosmoline it's best to use heat to liquify it and sweat it off. There are a lot of solvents you can use to help get the job done. I used some dollar store brand knock off WD-40 once and it worked great. There are a lot of guides for how to do this.

https://kurtthegunsmith.com/what-is-cosmoline-and-how-to-remove-it/

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56601156
Just doing some googling around the ballpark out of the box accuracy expected out of an M82 is about 3 MOA (or about a 3" dispersion at 100 yards) with ball ammunition which can go down to 1" or so with specialized match ammunition. That's pretty accurate, but it's not really designed as a precision rifle but more of a big-bore anti-materiel weapon used for damaging enemy equipment or blowing up captured/retired explosives at a safe distance.
Reading on the M99, the expected accuracy is also about 1" with match ammunition but it can do even better. As in one case where a 5 shot group of 4.09" was accomplished at 1000 yards. This makes sense as the barrel of the M99 doesn't move from shot to shot, whereby on the M82 it does (although the accuracy it can achieve despite that fact is still quite impressive).
>>56601138
It should be able to run everything. My older MKII does, but it has been around the block. Perhaps your MKIV being new not worn in yet. Keep shooting the ammo that you found works well and maybe try a little bit of the ammo you have been having problems with after a couple thousand rounds and a good cleaning.

>>56611906
Clean it as soon as possible after shooting. First you must use water, or something containing water, to wash out the corrosive salts. Then clean & oil as normal. Normal solvent or oil-based gun cleaners will not remove corrosive salts. You must use water for that job. Incidentally this is the same for black powder shooting, water is required to remove the powder fouling/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56613268
You can always shoot shorter shells than the gun is rated for but you cannot go the other way. For example, a 3" chamber can shoot 3" shells or 2 3/4", or the obsolete 2 1/2", etc. But you cannot shoot a 3.5" shell in a 3" chamber.

Really the only time this matters is if you will be hunting larger waterfowl like geese. Those really need the larger shells to perform worth a shit since lead shot was banned for waterfowl hunting. If you think you'll be doing that, get a 3.5". Otherwise it doesn't really matter, there is rarely a reason to shoot anything other than 2 3/4" shells--they're much cheaper for practice, and the bigger shells aren't any more lethal, they just have more recoil and mean you can't fit as much ammo in the tube.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56611906
Aside from what the other anons said, using hot or boiling water is preferable as it'll evaporate pretty quickly. There's no need to remove the action from the stock, just protect the wood with a rag in case a bit of water doesn't go straight into the chamber. It's generally not necessary to clean the bolt (especially if its a mosin). Whatever the method you choose, check your rifle a week or two afterwards just in case there's some light rust appearing in some spot.
If you can't clean your rifle within 24/48h, spray some wd40 down the bore once its cold. You can, prior to that, fire a single round of non corrosive ammo - it won't do wonders but still will help a bit.

The Japanese could not into ASW or effective convoy systems. By contrast, the UK/US wrote the book on both during the war. A big part of that was that by 1943, the Allies were basically able to provide air cover for convoys over the entire Atlantic. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56599529
Yup.
Radars got so good that they could spot a conning tower of a u-boat while it was on surface. And it got small enough that they could mount those radars on planes as well as sub-hunting warships. U-boats spend most of their time on the surface, only going under when they start attacking or evading, so they got spotted easily.

Then it was just a job to send a warship that had a sonar and a forward-throwing dept charge launcher to where a sub was spotted. Sonar would find the sub, and the warship could keep the sub constantly in it's sonar and throw depth charges at it. It didn't even need to go over it.

The only thing that the sub could do in that situation was to dive SUPER DEEP and hope that the deep water would mess up sonar return pings. Subs could not even outrun the warships, and the sub-hunters only needed to get lucky ONCE.

After that tech was widely available, the time of u-boats was over.

People mostly already said everything, but, to summarize: UK/USA could produce ships faster than Germany could sink them in all but like...4 months of the entire war and even then, only barely did losses exceed new construction. They actually built twice as much tonnage in the war as they ever lost and that is just merchant marine, not including USA/UK Navies. The U-Boat campaign only sank about 1% of trans-Atlantic shipping. The USA/UK had a huge merchant marine to begin with, high quality and numerous escorts, broken codes, better detection through centimetric radar (even in planes!), air cover, convoys, specialized and studied ASW tactics, specialized ASW weapons, experienced/high quality crews, etc.. Ship types had little to do with success, Germany's biggest successes came from breaking UK Naval codes and early ineptitude, not fancy technology or ships. The Battle of the Atlantic is the same as the Battle of Britain, the result was never really in doubt when we have 20/20 hindsight.

All Japan had going for it were defective USA torpedoes. Not only did they not have enough escorts, the destroyers they did have were used retardedly, like as troop transports. Japan's ASW was utterly hopeless and they lacked every element from production to a large merchant marine to air cover to proper RADAR detection, etc... There was even a study done that, had the USA had good torpedoes and focused entirely on anti-shipping, Japan would likely have collapsed militarily within a year (might have been even shorter, I don't remember the exact timeline).

>>56599654
Another issue--potentially even larger--was the doctrine that called for U-boats to report sightings back to Berlin prior to an attack. These radio messages were often picked up by Allied HF/DF sets, warning the convoy and giving them at least a direction if not a full triangulation. Berlin insisted throughout the war that HF/DF could never be made small enough to fit on a destroyer (in reality, it wasn't just on DDs, it was on 1000-ton DEs and corvettes), and the Germans were convinced that the Allies had some kind of super-radar (they *did* have centimetric radar, but the initial contact was often made with the HF/DF).

>Why does everyone laud the U-Boot fleet as some awesome force?
Because for a long period of time (1939-1944ish), they were the most obvious form of German success against Britain, which has highly valued its ocean trade for over five hundred years. The Battle of the Atlantic made headlines and newsreels in ways that land battles (especially with censorship) could not. The British public--and subsequently the Americans--projected a lot of their fears onto the wolfpack boogeymen.

posts.com:
This is directly from the designer of that blue camo:

>In Pre-2016 reform of the PLA, the marines’ missions involves amphibious warfare only, they weren’t expected to operate for long duration away from naval support.

>Amphibious warfare requires the attacking side to have total fire superiority. So when your ships are using direct fire to support a landing force, how can you tell friendly units from foe?

>Being able to differentiate your own troops, when you have total fire superiority is more important than being concealed.

>Back then PLA marines only had 2 Brigades of around 12,000 men total. So they are more of a specialized infantry, clearing beaches for the larger amphibious divisions of the Army. So, their mission is very situational.

>Another premise of PLA marines operate under, is that if you don’t have total fire superiority and must conduct an amphibious landing, then doing it at night is the only option.

>Otherwise, the potential casualties will be unacceptably high, So when you don’t need friend and foe identification due to the lack of direct fire support from ships, then night time camouflage under enemy night vision is more important.
To summarize, the role of the Camo needs to:

>Be distinctive enough to be used as friend foe identification, when your side have total fire superiority.
less visible during night time under enemy night vision, when total fire superiority cannot be achieved.
This blue camouflage pattern is pretty visible during daylight, giving the Chinese marines a rudimentary IFF (Identification Friend or Foe).

>This particular camouflage has been tested to be the least visible when viewed through night vision devices.

>>56595426
A lot of it was just unfamiliarity with how modern war was supposed to be fought.

Example: The French had a system wherein they would rotate units out from the front periodically because they didn't want the soldiers to revolt. The problem then is that after getting shelled for 60 days tens of thousands of French guys would be cycled back, and tell everyone else how horrifying it was, which was awful for morale because then nobody wanted to go to the front, and then they'd be sent BACK knowing what was waiting for them.

The Germans would just keep units on the front indefinitely until they were destroyed, and then deploy new ones. This had the advantage of keeping a lid on how fucked up it was, but it also meant that these veteran units would basically just be wiped out and then replaced with random conscripts.

The experience itself was also pretty awful, people didn't live in our stimulus-intensive world. Imagine if you live on some farm in Wyoming, your experience with loud noises is that you once saw a pickup truck and fired a shotgun at a racoon once. Then you get sent over to France and your next few months are being constantly within 50 yards of howitzers and machineguns firing. The Germans sometimes do it at night knowing that they're not going to hit anything just because they think it's funny, you haven't slept more than two hours in a row since 1914, everything smells awful, there are rats everywhere.

Then you "win" the war. Except what did you win exactly? Economy is in shambles, you've probably lost friends and family, you're partially deaf. For what?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56620580
>will likely have keymod under barrel instead of pic rail (saves space if you never want attachments)
If saving space is what you want you're going to have to create a detachable accessory rail instead. Also you're worried about space despite designing a gun who's front end is already significantly bulkier than a 1911.
With Keymod you're going to have to dedicate internal space anyways, not to mention the thickness of the plate with the hole(s). For all intents and purposes if you don't add any accessories you're going to end up with the same profile as picatinny.
It worked on rifles because the area between the handguard and the barrel wasn't used for anything but cooling anyways. Also you have more options to adjust a pic rail accessory to exactly where you want it.
Unless you're trying to make a multi-hole keymod thing were you slide in your accessory from the front and have a bunch of holes in the middle. That would be creative. Uselessly pointless, but creative.

I have the Leatherman Micra and while I don't own a Manager, I've had SAKs in the same size.

If you're only using it for light use, I'd go for the SAK. It's lighter and more compact. The tweezers/pen can be taken out if you need to use them for more delicate tasks.

If you need something (relatively) sturdy in a small package, go for the Leatherman. Scissors are fairly heavy duty for their size. While the tools don't lock, the folding style of the multitool makes it unlikely to close accidentally. Downside is its heavier and bulkier. None of the tools detach either--even the tweezers are integral.

Check your national knife laws then. As a russian, I know that Ka-Bar here is considered a cold weapon so you have to have a hunter's carry license to be able to buy a knife like this.
>brown rings for a grip but black polimer is acceptible if stronger
Those brown rings are made of leather btw, don't expect a full tang knife (the one where grip cheeks are attached to the tang by screws or anything like that) with those.
>Im not expecting it to be used any time soon to cut down trees or anything practical but I do not like to buy walhangers.
Try A&R Shtrafbat then. Stick tang, leather grip is avalible as an option, stainless steel, clipped blade. If you don't know how neither Ka-Bar nor NR-40 looked like, you may find this one fitting for your tasks.

>>56617927
Right around the early 60s there was a rumor spreading around the Air Force that during the Korean War an airbase was overrun and the entire garrison was destroyed because they mixed up the .30 Carbine and .45 ACP mags for their M2s and 1911s.
This never happened of course, but what was true was that Curtis LeMay understood that ground personnel were terribly untrained and underequipped to deal with ground security, and the face of tactical nuclear war meant that units might be isolated and have to fend for themselves for a long time (see: the army's pentomic restructuring)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56618410

Not hard. Like the other Norse guy mentioned. Have a clean police record, be 18 (or 20 for handguns), go to the nearest club and sign up for the brief introduction course, then become a member. Now you can go to an LGS and pick a gun. The shop will put it aside for you while you apply to the police for a purchase. This tends to be a ten week waiting period, but bureaucracy is bureacracy. For a handgun purchase you must first go somewhat regularly to the club shooting evenings for six months, but they all have guns you can loan (for free!) and ammo is available for purchase for the club at the same time. Even kinkier stuff like semi auto ARs are available if you have been diligent enough at shooting events and participated in competitions, or are a cop or an officer.

For you non-Norwegians: while we don't have the sheer volume of guns USA has or the kinkiest stuff, we still have a legal registered gun in just about every home. Indications are we have an unregistered gun in just about every home too...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56612265
I do occasionally when I have some laying around I want to shoot, it doesn’t even get close to cycling or even unlocking the lugs, it basically turns it into a giant single action, manually operated handgun. It’s pretty fun actually, also surprisingly quite.

The gold barrel is just for show mainly, but that and the silver are 6in barrels with compensators and the longer barrel is 10in, the shorter barrels feel very point-able and lighter on the muzzle than the .44 mag or .50AE 6 inches do. The 10 inch .357 is actually useful in that it gets .357 mag into the 1,800-2,000 FPS range, which is pretty insane even at range.

If I was going to pick two I’d either do .50AE and the silver .357 mag barrel or both the silver barrel and 10 inch, both in .357 mag. For pricing the black DEs run around $1,400 and the 6 in barrels are $600 a piece while the 10 in are $1,000.

Nope. 1960s 870, steel receiver. Take off your shell carrier, grab your original pins (or calipers if you don't have them), and check against the manufacturers specs. posts.name: Anonymous

>>56615872
>WTF is the point of choosing a load specifically meant for long distance if you're shooting at 15 yards?
Federal Flightcontrol is useful at any range further away than "the length of the gun". Keeping pellets together eliminates the risks of a flier hurting someone other than the intended target. Keeping pellets tight up close is even more important than granting the ability to reach further out.
>what's up with so many people shooting shotguns at static targets?
Uh, moving targets for anything but simulating birds takes a lot of work and expense? And owning enough land to build some mechanized target contraption on is basically a prerequisite on top of the difficulty and expense of actually building it. There isn't, afaik, any equivalent of a clay pidgeon launcher to send a torso size target running out in front of you. I guess you could stick it on one of those Boston Dynamics dogs and have it follow you into the woods and run around with your targets, but then we're right back to it being ungodly expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56617044
Yes, that is normal. The 686 needs the recoil of the shot to advance the trigger mechanism to the second barrel. When you dry fire it you're only "firing" the first barrel, and the ejectors only pop out for the barrel(s) that were fired so you don't eject a unfired cartridge.
